intro: Rosa canina var. spuria, commonly known as the dog rose, is a thorny shrub native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its pale pink to white flowers and red-orange hips that persist into winter. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and has alternate, pinnate leaves with five to seven leaflets. Its flowers are fragrant and bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The hips are edible and have been used in traditional medicine and culinary applications.
